user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of check_apply_param__threads:
```c
static void
check_apply_param__threads (void)
{
  if (0 == tool_params.threads)
    return;

  num_threads = tool_params.threads;

  if (get_process_cpu_core_count () < num_threads)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "WARNING: The requested number of threads (%u) is "
             "higher than the number of detected available CPU cores (%u).\n",
             num_threads, get_process_cpu_core_count ());
    fprintf (stderr, "This decreases the performance. "
             "Consider using fewer threads.\n");
  }
  if (get_cpu_core_count () == num_threads)
  {
    printf ("The requested number of threads is equal to the number of "
            "detected CPU cores.\n");
    print_all_cores_used ();
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The function check_apply_param__threads has no formal parameters (signature: void). Therefore there are no function parameters that could be modified, and Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified) cannot be violated within this function. The only assignments/uses are: reading tool_params.threads, assigning its value to num_threads (a local or global object, not a function parameter), and calling other functions (get_process_cpu_core_count, get_cpu_core_count, fprintf, printf, print_all_cores_used). Passing stderr or other values to called functions does not constitute modification of this function's parameters. No pointer parameters are declared or assigned to in this function, so the pointer-specific aspect of the rule (pointer parameter itself shall not be modified) is also not applicable. Consequently, there are no fragments requiring investigation for Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
